_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Dow Corning Corp. (www.dowcorning.com) is a member of the American Chemistry Council.  As such, the company uses the Responsible Care(R) management system to voluntarily improve its environmental, health, and safety performance.

Dow Corning?s Carrollton, Ky. manufacturing facility (www.dowcorning.com/carrollton) has implemented a Risk Management Plan. The company has established a Code of Business Conduct to guide its employees.  The facility maintains communication with the community through its Community Advisory Panel and other activities.

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies

Dow Corning uses policies and procedures to manage environmental, health, safety and security performance.  In addition, the facility has implemented safety and environmental management systems.

Facility overview and regulated substances

The facility manufactures chlorosilanes, methyl chloride, and silicone products.  The facility uses the following regulated substances:  anhydrous hydrogen chloride, aqueous hydrochloric acid, dimethyldichlorosilane, methyl chloride, methyltrichlorosilane, tetramethylsilane, trichlorosilane, and trimethylchlorosilane.

Accident prevention program

The facility uses a systematic approach to prevent accidental releases, which includes policies, procedures, training, preventive maintenance, safety reviews, change management, investigations, and audits.  The facility is a Star site in the Ky. Dept. of Labor?s Voluntary Protection Partnership (VPP) and has conducted security and vulnerability assessments through its association with the American Chemistry Council, Federal Bureau of Investigation, local law enforcement agencies, and the Coast Guard.

In addition, the facility has implemented chemical-specific accident prevention measures, including:

- Use of nitrogen to inert vessels and storage tanks
- Use of high-performance, corrosion- and wear-resistant materials
- Methyl chloride continuous air monitoring
- Au

tomated emergency shutdown systems
- Emergency cooling on methyl chloride reactors
- Emergency hydrogen chloride scrubbers

Five-year accident history

The facility reports the following accidents in the previous five years.  Accidents are investigated and followed up.  In May 2002, on two occasions contractors came in contact with chlorosilane vapors during equipment washouts and received medical evaluation.  In December 2002, an employee contacted methyl chloride during a maintenance activity, resulting in skin irritation.  In June 2003, an employee received minor first aid treatment after he inhaled chlorosilane vapors during an operational activity.  In October 2003, contractors inhaled chlorosilane vapors during a maintenance activity.  In November 2003, an employee received a slight chemical exposure from aqueous hydrochloric acid while dismantling piping.  In July 2004, one employee received chemical exposure from an aqueous hydrochloric acid release caused by a heat exchanger tubing failure.  He was treated and released to return to normal work duty.  As a precaution during the release, several nearby industries were asked to shelter in place; local roads and a river were temporarily closed.  In November 2004, two contract maintenance workers received first aid treatment due to chemical exposures from a trimethylchlorosilane release caused by a pipe gasket leak.

Emergency response program

The facility uses the Incident Command System for emergency planning and response activities.  The facility coordinates its emergency response plan with the Carroll Co., Ky. Local Emergency Planning Committee and can respond to any foreseeable emergency.  The facility also conducts periodic drills, trains emergency response personnel, and participates in community-wide drills.

Planned changes to improve safety

The Dow Corning Carrollton, Ky. facility strives to continuously improve its environmental, health, safety and security performance through management system and

equipment reliability improvements.  The facility uses a project-oriented approach to improve performance.

2007 Covered Process Changes 

One (1) newly installed covered process was added.
One (1) previously covered process was deleted since it has been physically removed from the stationary source.
Ten (10) previously covered processes were consolidated into three (3) larger covered processes since it has been determined that the consolidation was consistent with the RMP regulatory definition of a process.  There have been no changes in coverage of equipment or chemicals due to this consolidation.
